justification: "The most common way to assess hedonic capacity ... has been to use self-report questionnaires, such as the Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (Snaith et al., 1995)."
The same sentence lists the "Temporal Experience of Pleasure Scale (Gard et al. 2006)" as a tool for assessing hedonic capacity.
The article names "Chapman's Physical Anhedonia Scale (Chapman et al. 1976)" among questionnaires used to assess hedonic capacity.
It also cites "the most recently developed – Dimensional Anhedonia Scale (Rizvi et al. 2015)" for measuring hedonic capacity.
"A useful alternative could be the recently developed Positive Valence System Scale (Khazanov et al. 2019), which measures the Research Domain Criteria's ‘positive valence system’ subdomain."
In effort tasks "such as the Effort Expenditure for Rewards Task (Treadway et al. 2009) ... participants' valuation of rewards ... is inferred from their willingness to engage in physical effort."
The same paragraph references "the Incentive-Force Task (Prévost et al. 2010)" as another paradigm for inferring reward valuation from effort.

Risk-taking paradigms "such as the Cambridge Gambling Task (Rogers et al., 1999), in which reward value is indexed by the amount of money or points participants are willing to stake" are described as measures of reward valuation.
Reward bias tasks "such as the Probabilistic Reward Task (Pizzagalli et al. 2005)" assess how participants develop a reward response bias, indexing reward responsiveness.
"The most commonly-used neuroimaging paradigm is the Monetary Incentive Delay task (Knutson and Heinz 2015), which ... allows the separation of neural responses to anticipation and consummation."
